text: {"data":{"codelists":[{"annotations":[{"id":"origin","value":"INTEGRATION"},{"id":"isFinal"},{"id":"lastUpdatedAt","value":"2025-03-27T22:42:42.501147Z"}],"id":"CL_AFRREO_INDICATOR","name":"Sub-Saharan Africa Regional Economic Outlook (AFRREO) Indicator","names":{"en":"Sub-Saharan Africa Regional Economic Outlook (AFRREO) Indicator"},"descriptions":{},"version":"6.0.0","agencyID":"IMF.AFR","isPartial":false,"codes":[{"annotations":[],"id":"BXGS_BP6_GDP_PT","name":"Exports of goods and services, Percent of GDP","names":{"en":"Exports of goods and services, Percent of GDP"},"description":"The export (sale or barter) of physical, produced objects (goods) and services over which ownership rights can be established and whose ownership can be transferred from one institutional unit to another by engaging in transactions on markets by residents in one territory to residents in another territory. Exports reflect a change in the economic ownership of goods from residents of the compiling economy to non-residents, irrespective of physical movement of goods across national borders. The f.o.b. price (free on board price) of exports and imports of goods is the market value of the goods at the point of uniform valuation, (the customs frontier of the economy from which they are exported).  It is equal to the c.i.f. price less the costs of transportation and insurance charges, between the customs frontier of the exporting (importing) country and that of the importing (exporting) country. This indicator appears in other datasets published by the IMF. While every effort is made to ensure that estimates for the same indicator are consistent across different datasets, differences can occur due to differences in compilation methodology, reference year, splicing series to perserve time-series continuity, and when the data were collected, processed, and published. Value expressed as a percent of the Gross Domestic Product (GDP) of a country. A ratio expressed as a fraction of 100.","descriptions":{"en":"The export (sale or barter) of physical, produced objects (goods) and services over which ownership rights can be established and whose ownership can be transferred from one institutional unit to another by engaging in transactions on markets by residents in one territory to residents in another territory. Exports reflect a change in the economic ownership of goods from residents of the compiling economy to non-residents, irrespective of physical movement of goods across national borders. The f.o.b. price (free on board price) of exports and imports of goods is the market value of the goods at the point of uniform valuation, (the customs frontier of the economy from which they are exported).  It is equal to the c.i.f. price less the costs of transportation and insurance charges, between the customs frontier of the exporting (importing) country and that of the importing (exporting) country. This indicator appears in other datasets published by the IMF. While every effort is made to ensure that estimates for the same indicator are consistent across different datasets, differences can occur due to differences in compilation methodology, reference year, splicing series to perserve time-series continuity, and when the data were collected, processed, and published. Value expressed as a percent of the Gross Domestic Product (GDP) of a country. A ratio expressed as a fraction of 100."}},{"annotations":[],"id":"BMGS_BP6_GDP_PT","name":"Imports of goods and services, Percent of GDP","names":{"en":"Imports of goods and services, Percent of GDP"},"description":"Total current and capital account balances (credit less debit) Value expressed as a percent of the Gross Domestic Product (GDP) of a country. A ratio expressed as a fraction of 100.","descriptions":{"en":"Total current and capital account balances (credit less debit) Value expressed as a percent of the Gross Domestic Product (GDP) of a country. A ratio expressed as a fraction of 100."}},{"annotations":[],"id":"FDSAOP_GDP_PT","name":"Credit to the private sector, Percent of GDP","names":{"en":"Credit to the private sector, Percent of GDP"},"description":"CTP Value expressed as a percent of the Gross Domestic Product (GDP) of a country. A ratio expressed as a fraction of 100.","descriptions":{"en":"CTP Value expressed as a percent of the Gross Domestic Product (GDP) of a country. A ratio expressed as a fraction of 100."}},{"annotations":[],"id":"NGS_GDP_PT","name":"Gross savings, Percent of GDP","names":{"en":"Gross savings, Percent of GDP"},"description":"The portion of disposable income not used for final consumption expenditure, before deducting consumption of fixed capital. Value expressed as a percent of the Gross Domestic Product (GDP) of a country. A ratio expressed as a fraction of 100.","descriptions":{"en":"The portion of disposable income not used for final consumption expenditure, before deducting consumption of fixed capital. Value expressed as a percent of the Gross Domestic Product (GDP) of a country. A ratio expressed as a fraction of 100."}},{"annotations":[],"id":"FMB_GDP_PT","name":"Broad money, Percent of GDP","names":{"en":"Broad money, Percent of GDP"},"description":"Value expressed as a percent of the Gross Domestic Product (GDP) of a country. A ratio expressed as a fraction of 100.","descriptions":{"en":"Value expressed as a percent of the Gross Domestic Product (GDP) of a country. A ratio expressed as a fraction of 100."}},{"annotations":[],"id":"FDSAOP_PC_PP_PT","name":"Credit to the private sector, Percent change","names":{"en":"Credit to the private sector, Percent change"},"description":"CTP This measures the relative change in a value over time, expressed as a percentage. It is calculated as the difference between the new value and the old value, divided by the old value, and multiplied by 100. 1 A ratio expressed as a fraction of 100.","descriptions":{"en":"CTP This measures the relative change in a value over time, expressed as a percentage. It is calculated as the difference between the new value and the old value, divided by the old value, and multiplied by 100. 1 A ratio expressed as a fraction of 100."}},{"annotations":[],"id":"FMB_PC_PP_PT","name":"Broad money, Percent change","names":{"en":"Broad money, Percent change"},"description":"This measures the relative change in a value over time, expressed as a percentage. It is calculated as the difference between the new value and the old value, divided by the old value, and multiplied by 100. 1 A ratio expressed as a fraction of 100.","descriptions":{"en":"This measures the relative change in a value over time, expressed as a percentage. It is calculated as the difference between the new value and the old value, divided by the old value, and multiplied by 100. 1 A ratio expressed as a fraction of 100."}},{"annotations":[],"id":"BCA_BP6_GDP_PT","name":"Current account balance (credit less debit), Percent of GDP","names":{"en":"Current account balance (credit less debit), Percent of GDP"},"description":"The current account balance is the balance of current transactions (transactions in goods and services, earned income and transfer income) between residents and non-residents. The term current account balance is used in the external accounts and is expressed from the perspective of resident units. The term current external balance is used in the national accounts and is expressed from the perspective of the non-resident units, and therefore with the opposite sign.  Value expressed as a percent of the Gross Domestic Product (GDP) of a country. A ratio expressed as a fraction of 100.","descriptions":{"en":"The current account balance is the balance of current transactions (transactions in goods and services, earned income and transfer income) between residents and non-residents. The term current account balance is used in the external accounts and is expressed from the perspective of resident units. The term current external balance is used in the national accounts and is expressed from the perspective of the non-resident units, and therefore with the opposite sign.  Value expressed as a percent of the Gross Domestic Product (GDP) of a country. A ratio expressed as a fraction of 100."}},{"annotations":[],"id":"GGR_G01_GDP_PT","name":"Revenue, excluding grants, General government, Percent of GDP","names":{"en":"Revenue, excluding grants, General government, Percent of GDP"},"description":"Revenue refers to the total inflow of resources, typically in the form of taxes, fees, charges, grants, and other income, received by a government entity during a specific period. It represents the funds generated by the government through its various activities and sources, including taxation, sales of goods or services, investment income, and transfers from other entities. This indicator excludes grants receivable.  Grants are transfers receivable (payable) by government units, from (to) other resident or non-resident government units or international organisations, that do not meet the definition of a tax, subsidy, or social contribution. Central, state, and local governments, including their agencies and departments. Value expressed as a percent of the Gross Domestic Product (GDP) of a country. A ratio expressed as a fraction of 100.","descriptions":{"en":"Revenue refers to the total inflow of resources, typically in the form of taxes, fees, charges, grants, and other income, received by a government entity during a specific period. It represents the funds generated by the government through its various activities and sources, including taxation, sales of goods or services, investment income, and transfers from other entities. This indicator excludes grants receivable.  Grants are transfers receivable (payable) by government units, from (to) other resident or non-resident government units or international organisations, that do not meet the definition of a tax, subsidy, or social contribution. Central, state, and local governments, including their agencies and departments. Value expressed as a percent of the Gross Domestic Product (GDP) of a country. A ratio expressed as a fraction of 100."}},{"annotations":[],"id":"GGXCNLXG_G01_GDP_PT","name":"Overall balance, General government, Percent of GDP","names":{"en":"Overall balance, General government, Percent of GDP"},"description":"The overall balance represents the difference between a government's total revenue and its total expenditure over a specific period, typically a fiscal year. It reflects the net financial position of the government, indicating whether it is running a surplus (positive overall balance) or a deficit (negative overall balance). The overall balance takes into account all sources of revenue, including taxes, fees, and grants, as well as all types of expenditure, such as salaries, public services, and debt servicing costs. Monitoring the overall balance is crucial for assessing the government's fiscal health, its ability to meet its financial obligations, and the sustainability of its budgetary policies Central, state, and local governments, including their agencies and departments. Value expressed as a percent of the Gross Domestic Product (GDP) of a country. A ratio expressed as a fraction of 100.","descriptions":{"en":"The overall balance represents the difference between a government's total revenue and its total expenditure over a specific period, typically a fiscal year. It reflects the net financial position of the government, indicating whether it is running a surplus (positive overall balance) or a deficit (negative overall balance). The overall balance takes into account all sources of revenue, including taxes, fees, and grants, as well as all types of expenditure, such as salaries, public services, and debt servicing costs. Monitoring the overall balance is crucial for assessing the government's fiscal health, its ability to meet its financial obligations, and the sustainability of its budgetary policies Central, state, and local governments, including their agencies and departments. Value expressed as a percent of the Gross Domestic Product (GDP) of a country. A ratio expressed as a fraction of 100."}},{"annotations":[],"id":"GGXWDG_G01_GDP_PT","name":"Gross debt, General government, Percent of GDP","names":{"en":"Gross debt, General government, Percent of GDP"},"description":"Gross debt is the sum of all liabilities that are debt instruments.  Debt instruments are financial instruments that require the payment of principal and/or interest at some point(s) in the future. Debt instruments consist of SDRs, currency and deposits, debt securities, loans, insurance technical reserves, pension and related entitlements, provision for calls under standardized guarantees, and other accounts receivable/payable.  Central, state, and local governments, including their agencies and departments. Value expressed as a percent of the Gross Domestic Product (GDP) of a country. A ratio expressed as a fraction of 100.","descriptions":{"en":"Gross debt is the sum of all liabilities that are debt instruments.  Debt instruments are financial instruments that require the payment of principal and/or interest at some point(s) in the future. Debt instruments consist of SDRs, currency and deposits, debt securities, loans, insurance technical reserves, pension and related entitlements, provision for calls under standardized guarantees, and other accounts receivable/payable.  Central, state, and local governments, including their agencies and departments. Value expressed as a percent of the Gross Domestic Product (GDP) of a country. A ratio expressed as a fraction of 100."}},{"annotations":[],"id":"D_G_GDP_PT","name":"Gross external debt, Percent of GDP","names":{"en":"Gross external debt, Percent of GDP"},"description":"The total debt that a country owes to foreign creditors. Value expressed as a percent of the Gross Domestic Product (GDP) of a country. A ratio expressed as a fraction of 100.","descriptions":{"en":"The total debt that a country owes to foreign creditors. Value expressed as a percent of the Gross Domestic Product (GDP) of a country. A ratio expressed as a fraction of 100."}},{"annotations":[],"id":"TTT_IX","name":"Goods, Terms of trade (TOT), Index","names":{"en":"Goods, Terms of trade (TOT), Index"},"description":"Physical, tangible products that are traded internationally. The ratio of export prices to import prices, indicating the relative value of imports in terms of exports. A statistical measure that expresses the relative change in a variable over time.","descriptions":{"en":"Physical, tangible products that are traded internationally. The ratio of export prices to import prices, indicating the relative value of imports in terms of exports. A statistical measure that expresses the relative change in a variable over time."}},{"annotations":[],"id":"GGX_G01_GDP_PT","name":"Expenditure, General government, Percent of GDP","names":{"en":"Expenditure, General government, Percent of GDP"},"description":"Expenditure refers to the total outflow of resources, including payments, purchases, and transfers, made by a government entity during a specific period to fulfill its various functions and obligations. It encompasses spending on goods and services, wages and salaries, social benefits, debt servicing, infrastructure investments, and other government programs and activities. Expenditure represents the utilization of government funds to provide public services, maintain infrastructure, implement policies, and meet financial obligations. Monitoring expenditure patterns and allocations provides insight into government priorities, policy objectives, and fiscal sustainability.  Central, state, and local governments, including their agencies and departments. Value expressed as a percent of the Gross Domestic Product (GDP) of a country. A ratio expressed as a fraction of 100.","descriptions":{"en":"Expenditure refers to the total outflow of resources, including payments, purchases, and transfers, made by a government entity during a specific period to fulfill its various functions and obligations. It encompasses spending on goods and services, wages and salaries, social benefits, debt servicing, infrastructure investments, and other government programs and activities. Expenditure represents the utilization of government funds to provide public services, maintain infrastructure, implement policies, and meet financial obligations. Monitoring expenditure patterns and allocations provides insight into government priorities, policy objectives, and fiscal sustainability.  Central, state, and local governments, including their agencies and departments. Value expressed as a percent of the Gross Domestic Product (GDP) of a country. A ratio expressed as a fraction of 100."}},{"annotations":[],"id":"BG_BP6_GDP_PT","name":"Goods balance (credit less debit), Percent of GDP","names":{"en":"Goods balance (credit less debit), Percent of GDP"},"description":"The difference between the value of a country's exports and imports of goods. Value expressed as a percent of the Gross Domestic Product (GDP) of a country. A ratio expressed as a fraction of 100.","descriptions":{"en":"The difference between the value of a country's exports and imports of goods. Value expressed as a percent of the Gross Domestic Product (GDP) of a country. A ratio expressed as a fraction of 100."}},{"annotations":[],"id":"BFD_BP6_GDP_PT","name":"Direct investment, Net (assets less liabilities), Percent of GDP","names":{"en":"Direct investment, Net (assets less liabilities), Percent of GDP"},"description":"Direct Investment represents cross-border investment associated with a resident in one economy having control or a significant degree of influence on the management of an enterprise that is resident in another economy. Ownership of 10 percent or more of the voting power is evidence of a direct investment relationship.  Net refers to the value of assets less the value of liabilities Value expressed as a percent of the Gross Domestic Product (GDP) of a country. A ratio expressed as a fraction of 100.","descriptions":{"en":"Direct Investment represents cross-border investment associated with a resident in one economy having control or a significant degree of influence on the management of an enterprise that is resident in another economy. Ownership of 10 percent or more of the voting power is evidence of a direct investment relationship.  Net refers to the value of assets less the value of liabilities Value expressed as a percent of the Gross Domestic Product (GDP) of a country. A ratio expressed as a fraction of 100."}},{"annotations":[],"id":"ENEER_IX","name":"Nominal effective exchange rate (NEER), Weighted index reflecting all trade partner economies","names":{"en":"Nominal effective exchange rate (NEER), Weighted index reflecting all trade partner economies"},"description":"A nominal effective exchange rates (NEER) is a measure of the value of a currency against a weighted average of several foreign currencies. The weights are derived by taking a three-year average of the trade partners' combined value of imports and exports with the focal country as a share of the focal countries' total combined value of imports and exports. Weighted average value for a specific variable, reflecting the relative importance of all trade partners. A statistical measure that expresses the relative change in a variable over time.","descriptions":{"en":"A nominal effective exchange rates (NEER) is a measure of the value of a currency against a weighted average of several foreign currencies. The weights are derived by taking a three-year average of the trade partners' combined value of imports and exports with the focal country as a share of the focal countries' total combined value of imports and exports. Weighted average value for a specific variable, reflecting the relative importance of all trade partners. A statistical measure that expresses the relative change in a variable over time."}},{"annotations":[],"id":"IAR_BP6_MI_MH","name":"Gross international reserves, In months of next year's imports of goods and services","names":{"en":"Gross international reserves, In months of next year's imports of goods and services"},"description":"The total holdings of a country's central bank in foreign currencies, gold, and other reserve assets. It refers to a metric expressing a country's foreign exchange reserves (typically held by its central bank) relative to the estimated value of its imports in the following year. It indicates how many months of imports the country could afford if its reserves remained unchanged and its import levels were projected forward. This is a measure of a country's external liquidity and its ability to withstand shocks to its balance of payments. Each of the twelve named periods into which a year is divided.","descriptions":{"en":"The total holdings of a country's central bank in foreign currencies, gold, and other reserve assets. It refers to a metric expressing a country's foreign exchange reserves (typically held by its central bank) relative to the estimated value of its imports in the following year. It indicates how many months of imports the country could afford if its reserves remained unchanged and its import levels were projected forward. This is a measure of a country's external liquidity and its ability to withstand shocks to its balance of payments. Each of the twelve named periods into which a year is divided."}},{"annotations":[],"id":"NGDPRPC_PC_PP_PT","name":"Gross domestic product (GDP), Constant prices, Per capita, Percent change","names":{"en":"Gross domestic product (GDP), Constant prices, Per capita, Percent change"},"description":"Gross domestic product reflects the total income earned through the production of goods and services in an economic territory during an accounting period. It can be measured in three different ways: using either the expenditure approach, the income approach, or the production approach.  Prices that have been adjusted to a reference base year to remove the effects of inflation, allowing for meaningful comparison of the purchasing power of money over time. This reflects the real value of goods and services, as opposed to their nominal value (current prices), which can be distorted by inflation. This refers to the percentage increase or decrease in a particular value when calculated on a per-person basis. For example, it could measure the percentage change in income per capita or the percentage change in CO₂ emissions per capita. A ratio expressed as a fraction of 100.","descriptions":{"en":"Gross domestic product reflects the total income earned through the production of goods and services in an economic territory during an accounting period. It can be measured in three different ways: using either the expenditure approach, the income approach, or the production approach.  Prices that have been adjusted to a reference base year to remove the effects of inflation, allowing for meaningful comparison of the purchasing power of money over time. This reflects the real value of goods and services, as opposed to their nominal value (current prices), which can be distorted by inflation. This refers to the percentage increase or decrease in a particular value when calculated on a per-person basis. For example, it could measure the percentage change in income per capita or the percentage change in CO₂ emissions per capita. A ratio expressed as a fraction of 100."}},{"annotations":[],"id":"PCPI_PC_PP_PT","name":"All Items, Consumer price index (CPI), Period average, Year-over-year (YOY) percent change","names":{"en":"All Items, Consumer price index (CPI), Period average, Year-over-year (YOY) percent change"},"description":"All items in the context of the consumer price index indicates that the index includes prices for all items included in the consumer price index basket.  This includes prices related to food, beverages, clothing, housing, health, transport, communications, recreation, education, restaurants and hotels and other miscellanoues goods and services. The Consumer Price Index (CPI) is an index of the prices of consumption goods and services, as compared to a certain reference period. The percentage change over two consecutive years in the average value of an index for the current period compared to the previous period. This provides a measure of how the average relative value (compared to the base period) has changed over two consecutive periods. A ratio expressed as a fraction of 100.","descriptions":{"en":"All items in the context of the consumer price index indicates that the index includes prices for all items included in the consumer price index basket.  This includes prices related to food, beverages, clothing, housing, health, transport, communications, recreation, education, restaurants and hotels and other miscellanoues goods and services. The Consumer Price Index (CPI) is an index of the prices of consumption goods and services, as compared to a certain reference period. The percentage change over two consecutive years in the average value of an index for the current period compared to the previous period. This provides a measure of how the average relative value (compared to the base period) has changed over two consecutive periods. A ratio expressed as a fraction of 100."}},{"annotations":[],"id":"GGXCNL_G01_GDP_PT","name":"Overall balance, General government, Percent change","names":{"en":"Overall balance, General government, Percent change"},"description":"The overall balance represents the difference between a government's total revenue and its total expenditure over a specific period, typically a fiscal year. Value expressed as a percent of the Gross Domestic Product (GDP) of a country. A ratio expressed as a fraction of 100.","descriptions":{"en":"Acquisitions less disposals of fixed assets during the accounting period, including certain specified expenditures on services that add to the value of non-produced assets. Value expressed as a percent of the Gross Domestic Product (GDP) of a country. A ratio expressed as a fraction of 100."}},{"annotations":[],"id":"PCPI_EOP_PC_PP_PT","name":"All Items, Consumer price index (CPI), End-of-period (EoP), Year-over-year (YOY) percent change","names":{"en":"All Items, Consumer price index (CPI), End-of-period (EoP), Year-over-year (YOY) percent change"},"description":"All items in the context of the consumer price index indicates that the index includes prices for all items included in the consumer price index basket.  This includes prices related to food, beverages, clothing, housing, health, transport, communications, recreation, education, restaurants and hotels and other miscellanoues goods and services. The Consumer Price Index (CPI) is an index of the prices of consumption goods and services, as compared to a certain reference period. The percent change between the data points at the end of two consecutive years. A ratio expressed as a fraction of 100.","descriptions":{"en":"All items in the context of the consumer price index indicates that the index includes prices for all items included in the consumer price index basket.  This includes prices related to food, beverages, clothing, housing, health, transport, communications, recreation, education, restaurants and hotels and other miscellanoues goods and services. The percent change between the data points at the end of two consecutive years. A ratio expressed as a fraction of 100."}},{"annotations":[],"id":"EREER_IX","name":"Real effective exchange rate (REER), Weighted index reflecting all trade partner economies, adjusted by relative consumer prices","names":{"en":"Real effective exchange rate (REER), Weighted index reflecting all trade partner economies, adjusted by relative consumer prices"},"description":"A real effective exchange rate (REER) is a measure of the value of a currency against a weighted average of several foreign currencies divided by a price deflator or index of costs. The weights are derived by taking a three-year average of the trade partners' combined value of imports and exports with the focal country as a share of the focal countries' total combined value of imports and exports. An increase in REER implies that exports become more expensive and imports become cheaper; therefore, an increase indicates a loss in trade competitiveness. Weighted index adjusted for inflation differences between the country and its trade partners. A statistical measure that expresses the relative change in a variable over time.","descriptions":{"en":"A real effective exchange rate (REER) is a measure of the value of a currency against a weighted average of several foreign currencies divided by a price deflator or index of costs. The weights are derived by taking a three-year average of the trade partners' combined value of imports and exports with the focal country as a share of the focal countries' total combined value of imports and exports. An increase in REER implies that exports become more expensive and imports become cheaper; therefore, an increase indicates a loss in trade competitiveness. Weighted index adjusted for inflation differences between the country and its trade partners. A statistical measure that expresses the relative change in a variable over time."}},{"annotations":[],"id":"NGDP_R_PC_PP_PT","name":"Gross domestic product (GDP), Constant prices, Percent change","names":{"en":"Gross domestic product (GDP), Constant prices, Percent change"},"description":"Gross domestic product reflects the total income earned through the production of goods and services in an economic territory during an accounting period. It can be measured in three different ways: using either the expenditure approach, the income approach, or the production approach.  Prices that have been adjusted to a reference base year to remove the effects of inflation, allowing for meaningful comparison of the purchasing power of money over time. This reflects the real value of goods and services, as opposed to their nominal value (current prices), which can be distorted by inflation. This measures the relative change in a value over time, expressed as a percentage. It is calculated as the difference between the new value and the old value, divided by the old value, and multiplied by 100. 1 A ratio expressed as a fraction of 100.","descriptions":{"en":"Gross domestic product reflects the total income earned through the production of goods and services in an economic territory during an accounting period. This reflects the real value of goods and services, as opposed to their nominal value (current prices), which can be distorted by inflation. This measures the relative change in a value over time, expressed as a percentage.
